description: From Middle English reinbowe, reinboȝe, from Old English reġnboga (“rainbow”), from Proto-West Germanic *regnabogō, from Proto-Germanic *regnabugô (“rainbow”), equivalent to rain +‎ bow (“arch”). Cognate with West Frisian reinbôge (“rainbow”), Dutch regenboog (“rainbow”), German Regenbogen (“rainbow”), Danish regnbue (“rainbow”), Swedish regnbåge (“rainbow”), Icelandic regnbogi (“rainbow”).

entries.meaning: (attributive, chiefly US) Made up of several races or ethnicities, or (more broadly) of several cultural or ideological factions.
examples: That Asian-American actor Thomas Ikeda contributes a pleasingly frantic Panthino would not be considered rainbow enough.

entries.meaning: (poker, chiefly of a flop) Composed entirely of different suits.
(mathematics, cryptography) Of or pertaining to rainbow tables.
A multicoloured arch in the sky, produced by prismatic refraction of light within droplets of rain in the air.
Any prismatic refraction of light showing a spectrum of colours.
(often used with “of”) A wide assortment; a varied multitude.

examples: Many electoral promises are rainbows, vanishing soon after poll day.

entries.meaning: (baseball) A curveball, particularly a slow one.
(poker slang) In Texas hold 'em or Omaha hold 'em, a flop that contains three different suits.

examples: Finally, by actual trial, I have found that I can catch more rainbow by using one fly than with a two or three-fly cast.

entries.meaning: (figuratively, sometimes derogatory) A person within the LGBT community.
examples: Oh look, the rainbow came back.

verbs.description: rainbow (third-person singular simple present rainbows, present participle rainbowing, simple past and past participle rainbowed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To brighten with, or as with, a rainbow; to pattern with the colours of the rainbow.
(intransitive) To take the appearance of a rainbow.
(climbing) In climbing gyms where the rocks to climb are colored to indicate suggested climbing routes, to climb rocks of different colors, thereby ignoring such routes.
